entry.title: Mussels Shells Nature's Forgotten Canvas
entry.summary: Mussel shells, often overlooked and disregarded as simple sea debris, possess a unique charm when one takes the time to appreciate…
entry.content:
Mussel shells, often overlooked and disregarded as simple sea debris, possess a unique charm when one takes the time to appreciate their innate beauty. They are not commonly associated with jewelry materials, yet under the transformative influence of time and nature, these humble shells can become captivating pieces of art, adorning the necks of those who appreciate their subtle allure.

Initially, mussel shells are mostly ignored, strewn along coastlines or nestled beneath the sand. Their rough exteriors may not immediately captivate the casual observer. However, when left exposed to the elements for extended periods, they undergo a remarkable metamorphosis. The sun, salt, and sand gradually reshape them, smoothing their surfaces and bleaching them to a pale, almost porcelain-like blue and white. These shells, once considered inconspicuous, are now reborn as intriguing objects.

It is at this point that creative individuals find inspiration in these transformed mussel shells. Their newfound texture and color evoke the timeless beauty of weathered porcelain pieces washed up by the relentless tides of the ocean. What was once a common shell becomes a canvas for artistic expression. With a touch of creativity, these shells can be transformed into unique, arty necklaces that exude a sense of rustic elegance.

Arty, stylish people often gravitate towards such unconventional jewelry. They appreciate the fusion of nature's artistry with human creativity. The pale, weathered mussel shells, once considered worthless, now hold a special place in the jewelry boxes of those who seek to embrace their distinctive aesthetic. These necklaces, bearing the marks of nature's gentle touch and human ingenuity, become a symbol of appreciation for the beauty that can be found in the simplest and most unexpected places.

In conclusion, mussel shells, though not traditionally associated with jewelry, possess an innate charm when transformed by the forces of nature. Their journey from overlooked debris to artful necklaces is a testament to the creative potential that lies within the unlikeliest of materials. These shells remind us that beauty can be found in the most unexpected places, and with a dash of creativity, we can turn the ordinary into the extraordinary. It is in these moments of transformation and inspiration that the true beauty of nature and human imagination is revealed.

 

 
 
Regenerate

entry.title: The Jerry Mask
entry.summary: My inspiration for my humourous wall masks came from Beninese artist Romuald Hazoume. However his re-cycled masks have a more…
entry.content:
My inspiration for my humourous wall masks came from Beninese artist Romuald Hazoume. However his re-cycled masks have a more serious and political meaning....

They are made from discarded oil jerrycans and assorted dumping materials from industrial countries (having paid African nations to allow the dumping of their waste). 

His masks were exhibited and sold in mostly European galleries  and fetched handsome prices. The irony of sending the waste back where it came from was not a  coincidence!

 My masks story is a lot more mundane! I collect used plastic containers,  from restaurants, ice cream parlours, private consumers as well as fabric remnants and yarns from local factories overruns. Then the fun begins: cutting the containers, crochetting the yarns, assorting and cutting the fabrics, assembling it all!

The decorative property of the masks is surprisingly diverse and am so grateful when customers from all part of the world send me pictures of how they display them in their home.

entry.title: Embroidery and Applique
entry.summary: Embroidery and applique work have always been my passion, but I was using it mainly to refresh clothes , table…
entry.content:
Embroidery and applique work have always been my passion, but I was using it mainly to refresh clothes , table cloths or serviettes, too apprehensive to venture into artworks. This one was inspired by the war situation in Ukraine....I usually tend to use a more humouristic, cartoonesque style.

I  finally gathered courage and a local Hout Bay Art Gallery is exhibiting them....Yay!

a suivre!

entry.title: The Re-Cycling Bug
entry.summary: I received a huge box of remnants from Carole Nevin Design for which I am so grateful! This reignited my…
entry.content:
I received a huge box of remnants from Carole Nevin Design for which I am so grateful! This reignited my love of textiles and finding ways to use small pieces creatively.

Thinking out of the box they say, I took it literally and having collected a fair amount of 5liter plastic bottles ( a recent pipe burst episode in Hout Bay left us 4 days without running water) I decided to make some intriguing boxes out of them using Carole hand printed vibrant "Afrocentric" fabrics. As these sold pretty quickly from my little Spaza shop I soon needed more fabric. I visited Jay Smith, an other talented textile designer in Cape Town and came back with an other stash of heavenly textiles!

 

 

 To make the stopper a bit dramatic but staying with Nature I chose some dried indigenous South African plants, the eternal proteas being one of them!

Now the use for these is up to you.... jewellery box, secret box, pleasure toys, love letters you decide.

entry.title: Religion and Fashion
entry.summary: Wearing religious symbols as a fashion statement is sometimes frown upon.... I will not judge! My friends Dolce & Gabbana…
entry.content:
Wearing religious symbols as a fashion statement is sometimes frown upon....

I will not judge!

My friends Dolce & Gabbana made the crucifix fashionable so I take the liberty to imitate them using those symbols and design them in an African context

I used the wonderful book of African Ark  by Beckwith and Fisher as background for the display.

entry.title: The Year of the Scallop!
entry.summary: The Chinese Horoscope never thought of including the Year of The Scallop! Not only do they taste delicious but their…
entry.content:
The Chinese Horoscope never thought of including the Year of The Scallop!

Not only do they taste delicious but their shells are so attractive no wonder their elegant geometric design was very present in the Art Deco period. 

I have been dying them and turning them into summer necklaces.
 
Paired with pearls for the Chanel  look, Art Deco style. 

On a rope for a more casual Boho Chic summer look.

entry.title: The raffia inspo evolves !.....
entry.summary: Oops Instagram rejected this pic ......possible pornographic content!!!! The relaxation of lockdown and the summer around the corner seem to…
entry.content:
The relaxation of lockdown and the summer around the corner seem to be giving me a surge of energy. My jewellery style has always been very summer orientated perhaps due to the fact I was brought up in the South of France.

Saint Tropez has always been my inspiration.  I used to visit all those marvellous creative boutiques and rush home to try to make up similar clothes and fashion jewellery for myself. Little did I know that one day I would make it a business. Similarly my life in Cape Town constantly inspires me. The creativity of the place, the people, the climate, the beauty and the African flair are filling me with 'joie de vivre' and I love what I do!

entry.title: Jewellery with raffia
entry.summary: I always search for new ways to create jewellery that stands out, looks glamorous without the obvious precious metal but…
entry.content:
I always search for new ways to create jewellery that stands out, looks glamorous without the obvious precious metal but using organic elements, I like to call it "noblinglamour"!

I came across some natural raffia dyed in glorious colours and decided to experiment using it to frame shells, semi precious stones, coral, wooden beads etc. I am pleased with the results and the possibilities it offers...to be continued!

entry.title: The Slow Movement
entry.summary: We have been forced to SLOW DOWN during this pandemic and this might be the one positive aspect of this…
entry.content:
We have been forced to SLOW DOWN during this pandemic and this might be the one positive aspect of this painful period.

A lot of creative businesses are still struggling to stay afloat and I am certainly no exception. My 2 precious ladies have fortunately found new employment albeit not in the creative industry as for me as many of my artist friends I have been in limbo for the last 18 months. 

The jewellery side of the business lives on as it has a great following but the textile side being very tourist orientated I had to re-think! Having stacks of fabrics in my studio I started hand embroidery and applique and loving it. Yes it is slow but so therapeutic! My theme at the moment is cartoon and Picasso inspiration, humour has always been vital for me and don't we all need it now! So let's see where this will lead to....meanwhile am enjoying the slow pace.... breathe!!

entry.title: Face Masks the new fashion statement...who knew?
entry.summary: Little did I know whilst making my beloved textile African Masks that I would one day be making protective masks.
entry.content:
Little did I know whilst making my beloved textile African Masks that I would one day be making protective masks. From one day to an other the planet was turned upside down caused by a virus and forcing us to wear masks. Reluctant at first I have now joined the 'Masquerade' wearing them as we are forced to do and now making them trying to keep some humour in a situation far from laughable.

 Yours truly!
